abstract.p: Massachusetts Institute of Technology chemical engineering prof George Stephanopoulos is taking on challenge of reshaping Mitsubishi Chemical, Japan's largest petrochemical company, into player in nanochemistry, microreplication and the like (M)

block.p: So what do you do if you're 53 and have already had a been-there-done-that academic career? If you're George Stephanopoulos -- no, not that George Stephanopoulos; this one, unrelated, is a professor of chemical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology -- you switch careers and hemispheres. He is taking a stab at turning Japan's largest petrochemical company, Mitsubishi Chemical, into a force in the risky but profitable world of nanochemistry, microreplication and the like.

''I'm a member of the National Academy of Engineering, I have received the top awards that the chemical engineering profession can give, I've written 10 books, close to 200 scientific papers, graduated 45 Ph. D.'s,'' Mr. Stephanopoulos said earlier this month, just before Mitsubishi Chemical officially named him its chief technology officer. ''I had to rejuvenate myself intellectually and professionally.''

His wife and two children will stay in Boston, and the separation looms painfully. ''But they saw the gleam in my eye, and they all said, 'You've got to do this.' '' he said.
First, though, another task: a crash course in Japanese.
